subject: Boys Says Goodbye to TO
event:
So the Dallas Cowboys have released Terrell Owens.

Smartest thing that Jerry Jones has done in years.  Addition by subtraction.

I certainly hope that the Giants and the Jets both have the good sense to stay away from this guy.  He's a talented receiver, sure -- although age has started to catch up to him -- but he's also a locker room cancer.  

Most of ESPN's talking heads seem to feel that the only team that might take a chance on TO now is the Oakland Raiders.  Is even Al Davis that crazy?  Maybe so.  Sorry, Lodey.

The Cowboys also released Roy Williams.  The safety Roy Williams, not the recently acquired wideout Roy Williams.  Williams will have an easier time finding a new team than TO.  He's a liability in coverage, but he's still a hard hitter and a punishing tackler, might be useful as a role player in the right defense.

FWIW, I have been very pleased by what the Giants and Jets have been doing in free agency.  I was sorry to lose Derrick Ward ("Wind," from Earth, Wind, and Fire) from the G-Men, but he deserves the chance to start, and the Giants are still set at running back with Brandon Jacobs, Ahmad Bradshaw, and Danny Ware.  Meanwhile, they have been bolstering what was already a pretty formidable defense, picking up Michael Boley from the Falcons, Chris Canty from the Cowboys, and Rocky Bernard from the Seahawks.  Adding that trio to Osi, Kiwi, Justin Tuck, Fred Robbins, Jay Alford, and Barry Cofield should give the G-Men the most explosive pass-rush rotation in the league... and they were already pretty good at sacking the QB.

Meanwhile, the Jets have signed Bart Scott from the Ravens and Lito Shepard from the Eagles, and that should make their D a lot tougher as well.

As a fan, I've always loved tough D, so it's great to see both of my teams strengthening the side of the ball.

(Comments welcome, but only on the NFL, please)

comments.article:
I agree, Jerry Jones made a smart move for once. Whatever prowess Owens may have on the field is overshadowed by the damage he does to team chemistry, in my opinion.

He'd be a perfect fit in Oakland. To be doomed to several 3 to 5 win seasons in a row with the Raiders would be a fitting reward for T.O.

I've heard the Redskins might have an interest in T.O.

More power to 'em.

Hey, with a fanbase that dresses up as brigands and barbarians, the Raiders might actually be a good fit for TO.

Back in my hometown, we're all wondering: Is this the year the Detroit Lions start being a good team?1

And in my new home city, most people are waiting for the Seahawks to make the playoffs so we can start caring again. (Seattle's not much of a sports town, to be honest.)

--
1: No.

Don't forget about Jimmy Leonhard.  As a UW-Madison alum I loved watching him start this year.  Looking forward him playing in colors other than the Raven's even more.  He is a classy guy that didn't belong on that team.
You're not bothered by letting Laverneus Coles go?
I also love how Jones waited until the Skins had committed to Haynesworth so they won't be able to afford TO without some major restructuring.

TO's days were numbered, I always figured.

I read my Dolphins have been beefing up the O-line, acquiring Jake Grove as a new center. We'll see how that goes. Giving Pennington better protection would be helpful, especially if they play in the now-hot/now-cold fashion they did this past season.
The Jets have already said thanks, but no thanks to TO.

The Cowboys still have that lingering Jerry Jones problem, if one happens to be a fan.

Which I'm NOT! Ha Ha.
I'm surprised TO's head can fit in the door of ANY locker room. That guy's an egotistical jerk. Philly has been blessed to be rid of him.
I really don't like TO. At least I know the Steelers will never take him. (Heck, I just hope Pittsburgh picks up some good O-Line).

The major point I would argue would be this

he's still a hard hitter and a punishing tackler, might be useful as a role player in the right defense.


Roy Williams hasn't been a hard hitter in a few years now. In fact in the last season he was extremely ineffectual. Simply put, he should have been moved up to linebacker a while ago. Or cut, maybe, last season.

As for the Cowboys Receiving Core... how are they going to replace TO? Williams frankly isn't the answer. Owens has always been a good Receiver, can Romo be as good without TO?

Williams started off the year hurt. He only played in 3 games before put on injured reserve. He was a pretty effective guy his previous years, although he was a liability on passing downs for most of his career. I agree with George's assessment where he'd be effective in the right defensive scheme where he wouldn't be responsible in pass coverage.

As for the other Roy Williams... he never really had a chance to get started. He was still learning the playbook and with drama queen Owens crying for the ball, Romo didn't have much of an opportunity to pass to the guy. Providing he puts in the work in the offseason to learn the offense, I think he can and will be a viable option for the #1 receiver position.

I honestly thing Romo will be a better quarterback without Drops-a-lot Owens to worry about. Sure the guy is a phenominal athlete, but he was a lazy route runner and was prone to dropping the ball. He's either lead or been close to the lead in the league for drops. When a guy is getting 20+ looks a game and still crying for a ball, it's gotta get into the QBs head a little. Romo can focus on making the right reads rather than worrying about Owens now. It still remains to be proven that Romo can do that, but I think he has a better chance now than he did previously.

but my Titans will survive. I was pretty miffed to see the G-Men sign Canty though. He was supposed to have a visit with the Titans front office as well, but canceled it after his meetings with the Giants. Ah well, there is always the draft.

So far the off-season hasn't looked good for my Titans. The worst part is after this season, 6 of the 11 defensive starters will be free agents unless they extend thier contracts before Free Agency starts next year.

My team finally gets close to being a Super Bowl contender and now it looks like I will watch them self destruct over the next few seasons. My prediction for the AFC South... in a few seasons time Texans will be the dominant force. I hate it, but that's how it looks to me.
comments.subject: Fat Albert is gone...

comments.article: Way overdue.  Jerry Jones has made blunder after blunder with the roster moves over the last few years.  At least he realized that T.O. is one locker room cancer that needed to be removed.  Getting rid of Pac Man Jones was "smart" as well (I say smart because he was dumb enough to sign him in the first place).  All that being said...the defense is what fell apart toward the end of the season (I think Philly just scored again).  It seems like Jerry Jones is listening to someone (other than the voice in his head) who knows football, and is actually following sound advice.  This is a refreshing change.  Let's see how long this goes on until his ego resurfaces to wreak havoc on the team.
comments.subject: Thank God...

comments.article:
I never thought I'd say this but...the NFL offseason can be more traumatizing than actual season for this woebegone Broncos fan.

(But I have to say...9 players in about a week of free agency does say something about Bowlen's desire to win)

And the additions of Ryan, Scott and Lenoard will make the Jets pretty damn good, in my opinion.
If you think the NFL season is bad, don't become a baseball fan...

TO was and always has been an a-hole, but he's also happened to often be right. He was right about Mariucci and his run/run/pass-&-pray offense, even if TO was an unfair (and homophobic) a-hole about Garcia (who had too much pressure put on him by that conservative offense). I've always thought that Brad Childress and his giant ego were the real villains during the Eagle debacle, and, even if he was an a-hole to air it in public, McNabb *did* choke at the Super Bowl. And the problems at Dallas have less to do with team chemistry (why is that, if you read between the lines of the outrageously anti-Owens slant at ESPN, there were always a large group - if not a majority - of the Eagles and now the Cowboys *players* that liked TO?). Their problem is a spineless coach, an overrated QB, and an egomaniac owner who will never win another Super Bowl until he shares the limelight to once again allows better coaches to earn the respect they deserve.

But this is good, because now I can go back to hating the Jerry Jones-era Cowboys without regrets.

You sound just like TO....blaming others instead of taking responsibility for your own actions.

San Fran, Philly, and now Dallas...but hey, it's not TO'S fault....*laughs*
comments.subject: haha

comments.article:
I'd also like to point out the Jets' recent signing of Jim Leonhard (also from the Ravens), who has the potential to bolster the secondary and special teams. He did some pretty great things in the playoffs for the Ravens this past season; I also remember him fondly from his (excellent) days at Wisconsin.

At least it wasn't the Broncos. I don't know if I could bring myself to cheer for them - the Jets I can handle.
I heard something about the Ravens having interest.

NoooOOooooOOOOOooo!

Not my RAVENS!

I'm both sad and relieved that TO is gone. I'm not a huge football fan, but my mama raised me right. I support those Cowboys. I kind of feel like it's my birthright being a Texan and all.

Anywhoo, I was NOT happy when TO came to town. Not one bit. But somehow he grew on me. It's highly possible that the fake overdose was what really endeared me to him. I know, crazy right? But it gave him some vulnerability. And I saw emotional flaws other than just being an asshat. So then he became the underdog and for some reason I began to hope that through the magic of the Cowboys he could be groomed into a fine addition to the team. I so wish it could have been so. It makes me sad that it wasn't to be.

So I'm sad that we couldn't fix him eventhough he did settle down a bit. But I am happy that he is going as we really do need to find a good cohesive team that will work together again. We need to recruit leaders as well as good players. He's a good player, but he isn't anywhere Near motivating to a team.

TO has always been more of a natural old school Raider than a Cowboy.

I think he would be happy with the old Raiders of the 70's and 80's who were loose but good.

I'm sad to see Rocky leave my Hawks, but glad that he went to a team I don't seriously despise.

And it looks at least like the G-Men are looking up

comments.upictitle: Drooling Fan Girl: Art by HS Kim
comments.article:
Go Bills!!!

We are number 2!

I don't think the Raiders bite on TO. They've actually done a lot less gambling on nutcases in recent years.

Wherever he goes, he's going to be VERY unhappy with the contract he's forced to accept. Burned way too many bridges.

I'm very glad we picked up "Wind" but we still need about a half dozen other experienced players, after last week's bloodbath.

I still don't want to think about it.

You cannot win without a good defense and a great defence can win you a Super Bowl ala Baltimore and Pittsburgh recently.

Good defence can also keep you in a game better with turnovers and stops.

Your teams are doing better than the Lions or the Bills which are my regional teams.

I Have to say (quite thankfully) the Hawks won't be interested at all since they just picked up a fine receiver in T.J Houshmandzadeh. And he comes without the attitude issues inherent in a player like T.O.

I am wondering about this packer DT they signed though. I haven't the faintest clue about the solidity of Colin Cole. Either way, it's darn good to be back to talking football.
comments.subject: forgot to mention
